questionDown: On an axis in which moving from right to left is positive, what is the displacement and distance of a student who walks 32 m to the right and then 17 m to the left?

answers.a: Displacement is -15 m and distance is 49 m

answers.b: Displacement is -15 m and distance is -49 m

answers.c: Displacement is 15 m and distance is -49 m

answers.d: Displacement is 15 m and distance is 49 m

questionDown: Tiana jogs 1.5 km along a straight path and then turns and jogs 2.4 km in the opposite direction. She then turns back and jogs 0.7 km in the original direction. Let Tiana’s original direction be the positive direction. What are the displacement and distance she jogged?

answers.a: Displacement is -0.2 km, and distance is 4.6 km

answers.b: Displacement is 4.6 km,and distance is -0.2 km

answers.c: Displacement is 4.6 km, and distance is +0.2 km

answers.d: Displacement is +0.2 km, and distance is 4.6 km

questionDown: What does it mean when motion is described as relative?

answers.a: It means that motion depends on the frame of reference selected

answers.b: It means that motion of any object is described relative to the motion of any other object

answers.c: It means that motion is independent of the frame of reference

answers.d: It means that motion of any object is described relative to the motion of Earth

questionDown: What is the difference between distance and displacement?

answers.a: Distance has magnitude but no direction, while displacement has both magnitude and direction

answers.b: Distance has both magnitude and direction, while displacement has magnitude but no direction

answers.c: Distance has magnitude but no direction, while displacement has only direction

answers.d: There is no difference. Both distance and displacement have magnitude and direction

questionDown: Which situation correctly identifies a race car’s distance traveled and the magnitude of displacement during a one-lap car race?

answers.a: The perimeter of the race track is the distance, and the shortest distance between the start line and the finish line is the magnitude of displacement

answers.b: The perimeter of the race track is the magnitude of displacement, and the shortest distance between the start and finish line is the distance

answers.c: The perimeter of the race track is both the distance and magnitude of displacement

answers.d: The shortest distance between the start line and the finish line is both the distance and magnitude of displacement

questionDown: A pitcher throws a baseball from the pitcher’s mound to home plate in 0.46 s. The distance is 18.4 m. What was the average speed of the baseball?
Cassie walked to her friend’s house with an average speed of 1.40 m/s. The distance between the houses is 205 m. How long did the trip take her?
A trucker drives along a straight highway for 0.25 h with a displacement of 16 km south. What is the trucker’s average velocity?

Two runners travel along the same straight path. They start at the same time, and they end at the same time, but at the halfway mark, they have different instantaneous velocities. Is it possible for them to have the same average velocity for the trip?

answers.a: Yes, because average velocity depends on the total distance traveled

answers.b: Yes, because average velocity depends on the net or total displacement

answers.c: No, because the velocities of both runners must remain the exactly same throughout the journey

answers.d: No, because the instantaneous velocities of the runners must remain same midway but can be different elsewhere

questionDown: Is it possible for average velocity to be negative?

answers.a: No, average velocity describes only magnitude and not the direction of motion

answers.b: Yes, if the body keeps changing its direction during motion

answers.c: Yes, in cases when the net displacement is negative

answers.d: No, average velocity describes only the magnitude in the positive direction of motion

questionDown: Which of the following information about motion can be determined by looking at a position vs. time graph that is a straight line?
What information could you obtain by looking at a velocity vs. time graph?
What does your car’s odometer record?

answers.d: the sum of distance and displacement

questionDown: In the definition of velocity, what physical quantity is changing over time?
In a coordinate system in which the direction to the right is positive, what are the distance and displacement of a person who walks 35m to the left, 18m to the right, and then 26m to the left?
You sit in a car that is moving at an average speed of 86.4 km/h. During the 3.3 s that you glance out the window, how far has the car traveled?
If a biker rides west for 50 miles from his starting position, then turns and bikes back east 80 miles. What is his net displacement?

answers.d: Cannot be determined from the information given

questionDown: Four bicyclists travel different distances and times along a straight path. Which cyclist traveled with the greatest average speed?
A car travels with an average velocity of 23 m/s for 82 s. Which of the following could NOT have been the car's displacement?
A cheetah can accelerate from rest to a speed of 30.0 m/s in 7.00 s. What is its acceleration?
A woman backs her car out of her garage with an acceleration of 1.40 m/s². How long does it take her to reach a speed of 2.00 m/s?
What are three ways an object can accelerate?

answers.a: By speeding up, slowing down, or changing direction

answers.b: By speeding up, maintaining constant velocity, or changing direction

answers.c: By maintaining constant velocity, slowing down, or changing direction

answers.d: By speeding up, slowing down, or maintaining constant velocity

questionDown: What is the difference between average acceleration and instantaneous acceleration?

answers.a: Average acceleration is the change in velocity divided by the elapsed time; instantaneous acceleration is acceleration at a given point in time

answers.b: Average acceleration is acceleration at a given point in time; instantaneous acceleration is the change in displacement divided by the elapsed time

answers.c: Average acceleration is the change in displacement divided by the elapsed time; instantaneous acceleration is the acceleration at a given point in time

answers.d: Average acceleration is acceleration at a given point in time; instantaneous acceleration is the change in velocity divided by the elapsed time

questionDown: What is the rate of change of velocity called?
Dragsters can reach a top speed of 145 m/s in only 4.45 s. Calculate the average acceleration for such a dragster.
An Olympic-class sprinter starts a race with an acceleration of 4.50 m/s². Assuming she can maintain that acceleration, what is her speed 2.40 s later?
A cliff diver pushes off horizontally from a cliff and lands in the ocean 2.00 s later. How fast was he going when he entered the water? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
A girl drops a pebble from a high cliff into a lake far below. She sees the splash of the pebble hitting the water 2.00 s later. How fast was the pebble going when it hit the water? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
Identify the four variables found in the kinematic equations.

answers.c: Final Velocity, Force, Initial Velocity, and Mass

answers.d: Acceleration, Final Velocity, Force, and Initial Velocity

questionDown: Which of the following steps is always required to solve a kinematics problem?

answers.a: Find a suitable kinematic equation and then solve for the unknown quantity

answers.b: Find the acceleration of a body

answers.c: Find the initial velocity of a body

answers.d: Find the force acting on the body

questionDown: Which of the following provides a correct answer for a problem that can be solved using the kinematic equations?

answers.a: A body starts from rest and accelerates at 4 m/s² for 2 s. The body’s final velocity is 8 m/s

answers.b: A body starts from rest and accelerates at 4 m/s² for 2 s. The body’s final velocity is 16 m/s

answers.c: A body with a mass of 2 kg is acted upon by a force of 2 N. The acceleration of the body is 2 m/s²

answers.d: A body with a mass of 2 kg is acted upon by a force of 4 N. The acceleration of the body is 0.5 m/s²

questionDown: How can you use the definition of acceleration to explain the units in which acceleration is measured?

answers.a: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. Therefore, its unit is m/s²

answers.b: Acceleration is the rate of change of displacement. Therefore, its unit is m/s

answers.c: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. Therefore, its unit is m²/s

answers.d: Acceleration is the rate of change of displacement. Therefore, its unit is m²/s

questionDown: What are the SI units of acceleration?
Which of the following statements explains why a racecar going around a curve is accelerating, even if the speed is constant?

answers.a: The car is accelerating because the direction of velocity is changing

answers.b: The car is accelerating because the magnitude of velocity is changing

answers.c: The car is accelerating because the magnitude as well as the direction of velocity is changing

answers.d: The car is accelerating because neither the magnitude nor the direction of velocity is changing

questionDown: Which kinematic equation would you use to find the velocity of a skydiver 2.0s after she jumps from a plane and before she opens her parachute? Assume the positive direction is downward.
A motorcycle moving at a constant velocity suddenly accelerates at a rate of 4.0 m/s² to a speed of 35 m/s in 5.0 s. What was the initial speed of the motorcycle?

The driver of a sports car traveling at 10.0 m/s steps down hard on the accelerator for 5.0 s and the velocity increases to 30.0 m/s. What was the average acceleration of the car during the 5.0 s time interval?
A basketball decelerates at −0.20 m/s² from 2.0 m/s and stops at 5.0 seconds after noon. What time did it start rolling?
A swan accelerates from rest at 0.350 m/s² until it reaches 6.00 m/s. How far does it travel before takeoff?
Which variable represents displacement?
If velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s in 10 s, what is the average acceleration?
A bullet is accelerated at 6.30×10⁵ m/s² for 8.10×10⁻⁴ s. What is the muzzle velocity?
What is kinematics?

answers.a: Kinematics is the study of motion

answers.b: Kinematics is the study of the cause of motion

answers.c: Kinematics is the study of dimensions

answers.d: Kinematics is the study of atomic structures

questionDown: Do two bodies have to be in contact to exert force?

answers.a: No, the gravitational force is a field force and does not require physical contact to exert a force

answers.b: No, the gravitational force is a contact force and does not require physical contact to exert a force

answers.c: Yes, the gravitational force is a field force and requires physical contact to exert a force

answers.d: Yes, the gravitational force is a contact force and requires physical contact to exert a force

questionDown: What kind of physical quantity is force?

answers.c: Force is both a vector quantity and a scalar quantity

answers.d: Force is neither a vector nor a scalar quantity

questionDown: Which forces can be shown in a free-body diagram?

answers.d: A body that is not influenced by any force

questionDown: What does Newton’s first law state?

answers.a: A body at rest remains at rest, and a body in motion remains in motion at constant velocity unless acted on by a net external force

answers.b: A body at rest remains at rest, and a body in motion remains in motion at constant acceleration unless acted on by a net external force

answers.c: The rate of change of momentum is directly proportional to the external force

answers.d: The rate of change of momentum is inversely proportional to the external force

questionDown: Why does an object slow down when sliding, despite Newton’s first law?

answers.a: The object experiences a frictional force exerted by the surface, which opposes its motion

answers.b: The object experiences the gravitational force exerted by Earth, which opposes its motion

answers.c: The object experiences an internal force exerted by itself, which opposes its motion

answers.d: The object experiences a pseudo-force, which opposes its motion

questionDown: What is inertia?

answers.a: Inertia is an object’s tendency to remain at rest or, if moving, to remain in motion

answers.b: Inertia is an object’s tendency to remain at rest

answers.c: Inertia is an object’s tendency to remain in motion

answers.d: Inertia is an object’s tendency to maintain its mass

questionDown: What is mass? What does it depend on?

answers.a: Mass is the quantity of matter in an object; it depends on the number and types of atoms

answers.b: Mass is the weight of an object; it depends on the number and types of atoms

answers.c: Mass is the quantity of matter; it depends on gravitational force

answers.d: Mass is the weight of an object; it depends on gravitational force

questionDown: How much force needs to be applied to a 5-kg object for it to accelerate at 20 m/s²?
What is the mathematical statement for Newton’s second law of motion?
Newton’s second law describes the relationship between which quantities?
What is acceleration?

answers.a: Acceleration is the rate at which velocity changes

answers.b: Acceleration is the rate at which force changes

answers.c: Acceleration is the rate at which displacement changes

answers.d: Acceleration is the rate at which mass changes

questionDown: What is the equation for the normal force for a body with mass m that is at rest on a horizontal surface?
An object with mass m is at rest on the floor. What is the magnitude and direction of the normal force acting on it?
What is Newton’s third law of motion?

answers.a: Whenever a first body exerts a force on a second body, the first body experiences a force that is equal in magnitude but acts in the direction opposite the direction of the applied force

answers.b: Whenever a first body exerts a force on a second body, the first body experiences a force that is equal in magnitude and acts in the direction of the applied force

answers.c: Whenever a first body exerts a force on a second body, the first body experiences a force that is twice the magnitude but acts in the direction opposite the direction of the applied force

answers.d: Whenever a first body exerts a force on a second body, the first body experiences a force that is twice the magnitude and acts in the direction of the applied force

questionDown: Considering Newton’s third law, why don’t two equal and opposite forces cancel out each other?

answers.a: Because the two forces act on different systems

answers.b: Because the two forces have different magnitudes

answers.c: Because the two forces act in the same direction

answers.d: Because the two forces act in perpendicular directions

questionDown: What is dynamics?

answers.a: Dynamics is the study of forces and their effect on motion

answers.b: Dynamics is the study of internal forces

answers.c: Dynamics describes the motion of points, bodies, and systems without consideration of the cause of motion

answers.d: Dynamics describes the effect of forces on each other

questionDown: Two forces acting on an object are perpendicular to one another. How would you draw these in a free-body diagram?

answers.a: The two force arrows will be drawn at a right angle to one another

answers.b: The two force arrows will be pointing in opposite directions

answers.c: The two force arrows will be at a 45° angle to one another

answers.d: The two force arrows will be at a 180° angle to one another

questionDown: A ball rolls along the ground, moving from north to south. What direction is the frictional force that acts on the ball?
How do you express, mathematically, that no external force is acting on a body?
What does it mean for two quantities to be inversely proportional to each other?

answers.a: When one variable increases, the other variable decreases by a greater amount

answers.b: When one variable increases, the other variable also increases

answers.c: When one variable increases, the other variable decreases by the same factor

answers.d: When one variable increases, the other variable also increases by the same factor

questionDown: Which forces cause changes in the motion of a system?
A ball is dropped and hits the floor. What is the direction of the force exerted by the floor on the ball?
Only two forces are acting on an object: force A to the left and force B to the right. If force B is greater than force A, in which direction will the object move?
An object is at rest. Two forces, X and Y, are acting on it. Force X has a magnitude of x and acts in the downward direction. What is the magnitude and direction of Y?

answers.a: The magnitude is x and points in the upward direction

answers.b: The magnitude is 2x and points in the upward direction

answers.c: The magnitude is x and points in the downward direction

answers.d: The magnitude is 2x and points in the downward direction

questionDown: A person pushes an object of mass 5.0 kg along the floor by applying a force. If the object experiences a friction force of 10 N and accelerates at 18 m/s², what is the magnitude of the force exerted by the person?
Which of the following is a physical quantity that can be described by dynamics but not by kinematics?
Which of the following is used to represent an object in a free-body diagram?
What kind of force is friction?
What is another name for Newton’s first law?
A 2000-kg car is sitting at rest in a parking lot. A bike and rider with a total mass of 60 kg are traveling along a road at 10 km/h. Which system has more inertia? Why?

answers.a: The car has more inertia, as its mass is greater than the mass of the bike

answers.b: The bike has more inertia, as its mass is greater than the mass of the car

answers.c: The car has more inertia, as its mass is less than the mass of the bike

answers.d: The bike has more inertia, as its mass is less than the mass of the car

questionDown: In the equation for Newton’s second law, what does F_net stand for?
What is the SI unit of force?
What is the net external force on an object in freefall on Earth if you neglect air resistance?

answers.a: The net force is downward with magnitude mg

answers.b: The net force is upward with magnitude mg

answers.d: The net force is downward with magnitude 9.8 N

questionDown: Two people push a 2,000-kg car to get it started. An acceleration of at least 5.0 m/s² is required. If friction is 300 N, how much force will each need to apply?
A 65-kg swimmer pushes on the pool wall and accelerates at 6 m/s². Friction is 100 N. What force does the swimmer apply?
What is the angle in degrees between the hour and minute hands at 9:00 a.m.?
What is the arc length between the hour and minute hands at 10:00 a.m. if the clock radius is 0.2 m?
What is circular motion?

answers.a: The motion of an object when it follows a circular path

answers.b: The motion of an object when it follows a zigzag path

answers.c: The motion of an object when it follows a linear path

answers.d: The movement of an object along the circumference of a circle or rotation along a circular path

questionDown: What is meant by radius of curvature in rotational motion?

answers.a: The radius of a circular path

answers.b: The diameter of a circular path

answers.c: The circumference of a circular path

answers.d: The area of a circular path

questionDown: What is angular velocity?

answers.a: The rate of change of the angle subtended by the circular path

answers.b: The rate of change of the diameter of the circular path

answers.c: The rate of change of the area of the circular path

answers.d: The rate of change of the radius of the circular path

questionDown: What equation defines angular velocity ω?
What is the orientation of the radius and tangential velocity vectors in uniform circular motion?

answers.a: Tangential velocity vector is always perpendicular to the radius

answers.b: Tangential velocity vector is always parallel to the radius

answers.c: Tangential velocity vector is always at an acute angle to the radius

answers.d: Tangential velocity vector is always at an obtuse angle to the radius

questionDown: What is the centripetal acceleration of an object with speed 12 m/s and radius 2.0 m?
Centripetal acceleration of an object at radius 0.2 m and angular velocity 5 rad/s?
What is uniform circular motion?

answers.a: An object travels in a circular path at constant speed

answers.b: An object travels on a circular path at variable acceleration

answers.c: An object accelerates in a circular path with increasing velocity

answers.d: An object travels in a circular path at variable speed

questionDown: What is centripetal acceleration?

answers.a: Acceleration toward the center of the circular orbit

answers.b: Acceleration tangential to the circular path

answers.c: Acceleration along a linear path in direction of motion

answers.d: Acceleration along a linear path opposite to motion

questionDown: Is there a net force on an object in uniform circular motion?

answers.a: Yes, the object is accelerating, so a net force must be acting

answers.b: Yes, because there is no acceleration

answers.d: No, because there is no acceleration

questionDown: An object’s angular velocity changes from 3 rad/s clockwise to 8 rad/s clockwise in 5 s. What is its angular acceleration?
What is angular acceleration?

answers.a: The rate of change of angular velocity

answers.b: The rate of change of angular displacement

answers.c: The rate of change of linear displacement

answers.d: The rate of change of linear velocity

questionDown: What is the equation for angular acceleration, α?
Which of the following best describes torque?

answers.a: It is the rotational equivalent of a force

answers.b: It is the force that affects linear motion

answers.c: It is the rotational equivalent of acceleration

answers.d: It is the acceleration that affects linear motion

questionDown: What is the momentum of a bowling ball with mass 5 kg and velocity 10 m/s?
What will be the change in momentum caused by a net force of 120 N acting on an object for 2 seconds?
What is linear momentum?

answers.a: The product of a system’s mass and its velocity

answers.b: The ratio of a system’s mass to its velocity

answers.c: The sum of a system’s mass and its velocity

answers.d: The product of a system’s moment of inertia and its velocity

questionDown: If an object’s mass is constant, what is its momentum proportional to?
What is the equation for Newton’s second law, assuming constant mass?
Give an example of a system whose mass is not constant.

answers.b: A baseball flying through the air

answers.d: A block sliding on a frictionless inclined plane

questionDown: When is momentum said to be conserved?

answers.a: When momentum is constant throughout an event

answers.b: When momentum is increasing during an event

answers.c: When momentum is decreasing during an event

answers.d: When momentum is changing during an event

questionDown: A ball is hit by a racket and its momentum changes. How is momentum conserved?

answers.a: It is conserved if the momentum of the racket is also considered

answers.b: It is conserved if the momentum of the racket is not considered

answers.c: Momentum cannot be conserved in this case

answers.d: It is conserved if the momenta of the racket and player are considered

questionDown: State the law of conservation of momentum.

answers.a: Momentum is conserved for an isolated system with any number of objects

answers.b: Momentum is conserved for an isolated system with an even number of objects

answers.c: Momentum is conserved for an interacting system with any number of objects

answers.d: Momentum is conserved for an interacting system with an even number of objects

questionDown: In an elastic collision, one object's momentum changes from 25 to 10 kg⋅m/s. The other had 35 kg⋅m/s before. What is its final momentum?
What is an elastic collision?

answers.a: No internal kinetic energy is lost

answers.b: Some internal kinetic energy is lost

answers.d: Objects stick and move with common velocity

questionDown: Are perfectly elastic collisions possible?

answers.c: Possible only when objects stick together

questionDown: What is the equation for conservation of momentum in 1D?
In which Newton’s second law equation is mass constant?
What is the SI unit of momentum?
What is the equation for linear momentum?
Two objects collide with each other and come to a rest. How can you use the equation of conservation of momentum to describe this situation?
How much work is done when a weightlifter lifts a 200 N barbell from the floor to a height of 2 m?
Identify two properties that are expressed in units of joules.
A child slides down a playground slide. If the slide is 3 m high and the child weighs 300 N, how much potential energy does the child have at the top of the slide?
A 0.2 kg apple on an apple tree has a potential energy of 10 J. It falls to the ground, converting all of its PE to kinetic energy. What is the velocity of the apple just before it hits the ground?
Describe the transformation between forms of mechanical energy that is happening to a falling skydiver before his parachute opens.

answers.a: Potential energy is being transformed into kinetic energy

answers.b: Kinetic energy is being transformed into potential energy

answers.c: Work is being transformed into kinetic energy

answers.d: Kinetic energy is being transformed into work

questionDown: Identify equivalent terms for stored energy and energy of motion.

answers.a: Stored energy is potential energy, and energy of motion is kinetic energy

answers.b: Energy of motion is potential energy, and stored energy is kinetic energy

answers.c: Stored energy is the potential as well as the kinetic energy of the system

answers.d: Energy of motion is the potential as well as the kinetic energy of the system

questionDown: You know the height from which an object is dropped. Which equation could you use to calculate the velocity as the object hits the ground?
The starting line of a cross country foot race is at the bottom of a hill. Which form(s) of mechanical energy of the runners will change when the starting gun is fired?
How does a simple machine make work easier?

answers.a: It reduces the input force and increases the output force

answers.b: It reduces the input force and the output force

answers.c: It increases the input force and reduces the output force

answers.d: It increases the input force and the output

questionDown: Which expression represents power?
A car’s engine generates 100000 W of power as it exerts a force of 10000 N. How long does it take the car to travel 100 m?
What is the kinetic energy of a 10 kg object moving at 2.0 m/s?
What is 12.0 °C in kelvins?
What is 32.0 °C in degrees Fahrenheit?
What is thermal energy?

answers.a: The total potential energy of the particles in a system

answers.b: The average potential energy of the particles

answers.c: The average kinetic energy due to particle interaction

answers.d: The average kinetic energy of the particles in a system

questionDown: What is used to measure temperature?
How much heat does it take to raise the temperature of 10.0 kg of water by 1.0 °C? (Specific heat of water: 4200 J/kg·°C)
Calculate the change in temperature of 1.0 kg of water initially at room temperature if 3.0 kJ of heat is added. (Specific heat of water: 4200 J/kg·°C)
What causes heat transfer?

answers.a: The temperature difference between two systems causes heat transfer

answers.b: The density difference between two objects causes heat transfer

answers.c: The mass difference between two objects causes heat transfer

answers.d: The pressure difference between two objects causes heat transfer

questionDown: What are the different methods of heat transfer?
How much energy is needed to melt 2.00 kg of ice at 0 °C? Latent heat of fusion Lf = 334 kJ/kg
If 2500 kJ of energy is just enough to melt 3.0 kg of a substance, what is the substance’s latent heat of fusion?
In which phases of matter are molecules capable of changing their positions?
A glass of water has a temperature of 31 degrees Celsius. What state of matter is it in?
What are the SI units of specific heat?
What is 100.00 °C in kelvins?
5290 J of heat is given to 0.500 kg of water at 15.00 °C. What will its final temperature be? (c = 4200 J/kg·°C)
How much energy would it take to heat 1.00 kg of ice at 0 °C to water at 15.0 °C? (c = 4200 J/kg·°C, Lf = 334 kJ/kg)
What is absolute zero on the Fahrenheit scale?
What is absolute zero on the Celsius scale?
What is thermal equilibrium?

answers.a: When two objects in contact with each other are at the same temperature, they are said to be in thermal equilibrium

answers.b: When two objects in contact with each other are at different temperatures, they are said to be in thermal equilibrium

answers.c: When two objects in contact with each other are at the same pressure, they are said to be in thermal equilibrium

answers.d: When two objects not in contact with each other are at the same pressure, they are said to be in thermal equilibrium

questionDown: What is the zeroth law of thermodynamics?

answers.a: If two systems, A and B, are in thermal equilibrium with each another, and B is in thermal equilibrium with a third system, C, then A is also in thermal equilibrium with C

answers.b: Entropy of a system approaches a constant value as temperature approaches absolute zero

answers.c: Entropy of any isolated system not in thermal equilibrium always increases

answers.d: Energy can neither be created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction

questionDown: What is the pressure-volume work done by a system if a pressure of 20 Pa causes a change in volume of 3.0 m³?
What is the net heat out of the system when 25 J is transferred by heat into the system and 45 J is transferred out of it?
What is pressure?

answers.a: Pressure is force divided by area

answers.b: Pressure is force divided by length

answers.c: Pressure is force divided by volume

answers.d: Pressure is force divided by mass

questionDown: What is the SI unit for pressure?
What is pressure-volume work?

answers.a: It is the work that is done by a force on an object to produce a certain displacement.

answers.b: It is the work that is done by the compression or expansion of a fluid.

answers.c: It is the work that is done by the surface molecules of a fluid.

answers.d: It is the work that is done by the high-energy molecules of a fluid.

questionDown: When is pressure-volume work said to be done ON a system?

answers.a: When there is a decrease in volume and an increase in internal pressure.

answers.b: When there is a decrease in both volume and internal pressure.

answers.c: When there is an increase in both volume and internal pressure.

answers.d: When there is an increase in volume and a decrease in internal pressure.

questionDown: What are the ways to add energy to or remove energy from a system?

answers.a: Transferring energy by heat or by doing work are the ways to add energy to or remove energy from a system

answers.b: Doing compression work is the only way to add energy to or remove energy from a system

answers.c: Doing expansion work is the only way to add energy to or remove energy from a system

answers.d: Transferring energy by heat is the only way to add energy to or remove energy from a system

questionDown: What is internal energy?

answers.a: It is the sum of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules

answers.b: It is the sum of the potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules

answers.c: It is the sum of the kinetic energies of a system’s atoms and molecules

answers.d: It is the difference between the magnitudes of the kinetic and potential energies of a system’s atoms and molecules

questionDown: If  30.0 J are added by heat to water at 12C , what is the change in entropy?
What is the increase in entropy when 3.00 kg of ice at C o 0 melt to form water at C o 0 . ( Lf = 334kJ / kg ) ?
What is entropy?

answers.a: Entropy is a measure of the disorder of a system

answers.b: Entropy is a measure of the net work done by a system

questionDown: Which forms of energy can be used to do work?

answers.b: Only heat is able to do work

answers.c: Only internal energy is able to do work

answers.d: Only work is able to do work

questionDown: What is the statement for the second law of thermodynamics?

answers.b: All the spontaneous processes result in increased total entropy of a system

answers.c: All the spontaneous processes result in decreased or constant total entropy of a system

answers.d: All the spontaneous processes result in decreased total entropy of a system

answers.d: Thermal efficiency is the ratio of work output to the energy output

answers.d: When they are in thermal contact and are at different pressures

questionDown: Why does thermal expansion occur?

answers.a: An increase in temperature causes intermolecular distances to increase.

answers.b: An increase in temperature causes intermolecular distances to decrease.

answers.c: An increase in temperature causes an increase in the work done on the system.

answers.d: An increase in temperature causes an increase in the work done by the system.

questionDown: How does pressure-volume work relate to heat and internal energy of a system?

answers.a: The energy added to a system by heat minus the change in the internal energy of that system is equal to the pressure-volume work done by the system

answers.b: The sum of the energy released by a system by heat and the change in the internal energy of that system is equal to the pressure-volume work done by the system

answers.c: The product of the energy added to a system by heat and the change in the internal energy of that system is equal to the pressure-volume work done by the system

answers.d: If the energy added to a system by heat is divided by the change in the internal energy of that system, the quotient is equal to the pressure-volume work done by the system

questionDown: In a photovoltaic cell, what energy transformation takes place?

answers.A: Solar energy transforms into electric energy

answers.B: Solar energy transforms into mechanical energy

answers.C: Solar energy transforms into thermal energy

answers.D: In a photovoltaic cell, thermal energy transforms into electric energy

questionDown: What is a photon and how is it different from other fundamental particles?

answers.A: A photon is a quantum packet of energy; it is massless

answers.B: A photon is a quantum packet of energy; it has infinite mass.

answers.C: A photon is a fundamental particle of an atom; it has infinite mass

answers.D: A photon is a fundamental particle of an atom; it is massless
